title: How popular is African music outside Africa? - Quora

response.answer_text: How popular is African music outside Africa? I'm not sure how popular African music is in western countries, but I can tell you which artists I enjoy and have spent money on. Cheb Mami - AlgérieYoussou N'Dour - SénégalAli Farka Touré - MaliCheb Mami has worked with Sting, Ziggy Marley, and Zucchero. Youssou N'Dour has worked Zucchero, Peter Gabriel, and recorded a duet with Neneh Cherry. Ali Farka Touré recorded a CD with Ry Cooder and was an amazing blues guitarist. Those are just a few examples from my regular playlists. There are so many others, a world of beautiful and amazing music just waiting to be discovered. Just listen :-) If Carlos Santana can make a guitar sing and cry, then Ali Farka Touré could also make it slow up and touch your soul.  Ali Farka Touré - Cinquante Six  Youssou N'Dour with Neneh Cherry - 7 Seconds  Cheb Mami - Viens Habibi  Ali Farka Touré with Jools Holland - Diaraby  Youssou N'Dour - Marley  Sting with Cheb Mami - Desert Rose  Ali Farka Touré with Ry Cooder - Ai Du  Peter Gabriel with Youssou N'Dour - In Your Eyes  Zucchero with Cheb Mami - Cosi Celeste

It is not a mainstream genre, but it definitely has its fans in the UK. The music of Fela Kuti - Afrobeat - is quite hip in some circles in the UK and US. Nigerian pop music: in the shadow of Fela Kuti The last African artist I saw in concert was Kanda Bongo Man, who is Congolese, at the Royal Festival Hall in London. It is in any case hard to speak of ‘African’ music as a whole, as it is so diverse. I have played with musicians from Benin, Nigeria and South Africa, and the influences and styles are different. South African musicians were very active in London when I was playing live in the 80s, because they were refugees from apartheid, so they influenced a lot of other jazz and soul/r& b musicians then. I know that lots of styles have developed all over the continent in the many years since then.
